title: FCC to Provide Broadband Internet Discount to Offset Pandemic Income Loss
sub_head: Program to offer certain households a discount of up to $50 a month will be set up within 60 days
body:
WASHINGTON—The federal government is preparing to offer needy households a discount of up to $50 a month on broadband service during the Covid-19 pandemic.
The Federal Communications Commission said Thursday that it would set up a program within 60 days, after its four members unanimously voted to approve it. Congress set aside $3.2 billion for the initiative in a pandemic relief law passed late last year.
FCC Acting Chairwoman Jessica Rosenworcel said the program is the largest ever to help U.S. households afford broadband service. “It’s a challenge that is all too real for too many families,” she said.
Details about the program, such as how and where to apply, aren’t available.
The Emergency Broadband Benefit is open to households that meet one of a number of criteria, including having lost jobs or seen income reduced in the past year. It would also be available to people who participate in aid programs such as reduced-price school meals, student Pell grants, Lifeline subsidies for telecom service and low-income or emergency pandemic programs from private broadband providers.  It offers up to a $50-a-month discount on broadband service, rising to $75 a month for households on tribal lands. Discounts of $100 on a computer or tablet may also be available.
